intro: Orobanche insignis, commonly known as the Indian broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is found in various regions of India and Southeast Asia. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a unique reproductive strategy involving seed dormancy and germination in response to host root exudates. Its lack of leaves and stems makes it appear as a cluster of small, yellowish structures at the base of its host. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly impact the growth of its host plants, making it both a botanical curiosity and an agricultural concern.
